pages.subdeck: Catching some rays ... personal trainer Tara Hammett at Langland Bay, near Swansea, south Wales
pages.headline: Britain soaks up the sun as 21C heatwave hits - and it'll last
pages.teaser: GLORIOUS sunshine and baking heat expected to last into next week and beyond
pages.articlebody:
BRITAIN is basking in glorious sunshine today  with temperatures soaring to more than DOUBLE the March average.

Thousands of sun-seekers headed for beaches and parks to soak up some rays as the mercury rose above 21C, making the UK hotter than the Costa del Sol and resorts in Portugal.

The warmest place in Britain was Swansea, south Wales, where 21.7C was recorded at lunch time - and daytrippers including personal trainer Tara Hammett made the most of it on the sandy beaches.

Forecaster Paul Mott said temperatures are well in excess of expectations for this time of year, and added the heatwave, caused by high pressure, is expected to continue tomorrow and into next week

He described the current spell of warm weather as "quite unusual" for March, and warned there was no significant rainfall in the drought-affected areas of southern England.

He said: "It's looking fine and warm for much of the coming week. It will last until at least Thursday or Friday and will probably be milder next weekend."

Gardeners at Cornish National Trust mansion Cotehele were celebrating today as the peak blossom time of their daffodils has coincided with their annual weekend celebrating the plant.

A spokesman said it is the first time in four years they have got their timing perfect for the two-day event.

Senior gardener Aimee Kingdom said: "It's a fantastic chance for garden lovers and families to see our wonderful collection of historic daffodils, including some varieties which are 200 years old."

At the National Trust's Cotehele estate in Cornwall, hundreds of people took advantage of the good weather to see more than 150 varieties of daffodils that grow in the grounds of the Tudor house.

For the first time in four years the annual daffodil weekend is taking place while the flowers are at their peak and the orchards and gardens at the property near Plymouth was bursting with colours.

Vicky Dillon, one of the gardeners at Cotehele, said the Tamar Valley in which the house and gardens are situated has its own microclimate.

This has historically made it excellent for growing anything from flowers to soft fruits like strawberries.

He said: "It was very much a market garden industry at one point and a lot of the daffodils were grown for the cut flower industry.

"The daffodils were thrown away into the hedgerows at one point in the Second World War when the land was needed for food and they have survived in the hedgerows and woodlands because of that.

"We were able to gather a large selection of the daffodils from the estate and preserve them for future generations so people can enjoy them.

"A lot of the varieties we have got in the gardens are what I call 'nice and delicate', they are not the big and blousy ones you see now; they are pastel shades, pale colours, very small flowers and they have their own character."

pages.subdeck: Salute ... the fans' tribute to brave Muamba
pages.headline: Fans show support for brave Muamba as Bolton return to the pitch
pages.teaser: CLUB chairman Phil Gartside writes open letter to fans about hero midfielder
pages.articlebody:
FANS and players paid tribute to stricken Bolton hero Fabrice Muamba as Wanderers won their first match since the stricken star's collapse.

The home crowd held up hundreds of banners to create a giant mosaic spelling out the 23-year-old's name and his shirt number before kick-off.

There were emotional scenes before and after the game which Bolton won 2-1 at the Reebok Stadium.

Bolton players wore shirts with "Get well soon Fab" on the front and his name and number on the back in tribute to Muamba during warm-up.

And at Arsenal - the club where Muamba started his career - fans unfurled an enormous banner showing their support.

It comes after the star suffered a near-fatal heart attack on the pitch last Sunday during Bolton's FA Cup quarter-final match at Tottenham.

A huge spread of tributes was also laid outside the Reebok Stadium this morning.

Earlier, Bolton chairman Phil Gartside wrote an open letter to fans thanking them for backing midfielder Muamba, who remains in hospital in London.

He wrote: "I am writing on behalf of Fabrice's family, to pass on to Wanderers fans and the people of Bolton their sincere gratitude and thanks for the love and support they have received from you.

"As I am sure you are aware, the response has been amazing with messages and gestures of support from all around the world, inside and outside of football.

"I have been humbled to witness first-hand the power of positive thought while spending time with Fabrice's fiancie Shauna and his father Marcel.

"They in turn have drawn great strength from all the kindness and concern that has been shown.

"I personally want to thank you all for the support you have given Fabrice's family and also pay tribute to our fans that were at White Hart Lane.

"Throughout those difficult moments they were dignified, resolute and an absolute credit not only to Bolton Wanderers, but football.

"Our club doctor Jonathan Tobin has said the only time anything ever broke into his consciousness while he was on the pitch tending to Fabrice, was when the Spurs fans joined in with our supporters and began singing Fabrice's name, 35,000 people willing him on, together.

"We will be at the Reebok today, together, to support Fabrice. He is still in intensive care and still in a serious condition but, as Owen has said, Fabrice is a fighter.

"I would ask you all to keep him in your thoughts and prayers."

Bolton manager Owen Coyle also spent much of the week at the London Chest Hospital, where Muamba was rushed following his cardiac arrest.

He added: "If Fabrice can show what a battler is, I am sure we can play a football match."

Muamba's family have also praised fans for their support since the player's cardiac arrest and said God had answered their prayers.

Marcel Muamba and Shauna Magunda expressed their "enormous gratitude" to the Bolton and Tottenham medical teams for their quick reaction and praised the "fantastic team" caring for him at the London Chest Hospital.

Mr Muamba and Ms Magunda said: "We would like to firstly thank God for answering our prayers.

"The support we have had from the fans - not just from Bolton but football supporters around the world - has given us so much strength."

pages.subdeck: Record ... Davina McCall and Dermot O'Leary announce £50m record
pages.headline: Brits dig deep to raise record £50m for Sport Relief
pages.teaser: GENEROUS Brits dug deep to donate a record amount during last night's telethon
pages.articlebody:
GENEROUS Brits dug deep to donate a record £50million to Sport Relief during last night's charity telethon.

Celebs Gary Lineker, Davina McCall, James Corden, Claudia Winkleman, David Walliams and Miranda Hart hosted the evening of music and comedy.

Donations flooded in from across the country, with the total standing at £50,447,197.

Even more cash will be raised tomorrow, when more than a million people are expected to run the Sport Relief mile.

The money will be used to help disadvantaged people in the UK and worldwide.

Highlights of last night's show saw funnyman Frank Skinner come to grips with his fear of water, swimming just one length of his local pool.

After completing the challenge, Frank, 55, said: "I'm absolutely knocked out. I'm so relieved and excited. I lay in bed last night thinking about all the different ways I wouldn't finish that length.

"I want someone to learn to swim because of this. I know it looked really tough and frightening but I've had a good laugh and it will stay with me forever."

Benidorm's Got Talent saw the cast of the sitcom Benidorm auditioning in front of Britain's Got Talent judges David Walliams, Alesha Dixon, Carmen Electra and Simon Cowell.

But Cowell was unimpressed, saying: "I've done this a while and this was arguably one of the worst groups I've heard in my life."

Also some of England's top footballers, including current captain Scott Parker, Theo Walcott, Rob Green and Glen Johnson, donned their aprons for the Saturday Kitchen omelette challenge with chef James Martin.

And fashion-mad duo Edina and Patsy returned to the small screen with a one-off special of Absolutely Fabulous, with cameos from Kate Moss, Stella McCartney, Linford Christie and Colin Jackson.

Boyband JLS visited a hospital in Uganda and were moved by what they saw. Band member Marvin Humes said: "There are so many kids in here and they're all not well. It's amazing how young they are. It's just not right."

International Development Secretary Andrew Mitchell announced yesterday that the government will match £10million of public donations.

But the Premier League was slammed on Twitter for its "pathetic" donation.

The megabucks organisation, which boasted a turnover more an £1billion in the last financial year, donated just £250,000.

Viewer Beth Parker tweeted: "All the money the Premier League have and they only donate £250,000 to Sport Relief! What a joke!"

Another, Pat Eccles, added: "Congratulations to the Premier League for using all their resources and scraping together £250,000 for Sport Relief. Pathetic."

Other businesses were more generous, with Sports Direct and its customers managing £1million and Sainsbury's and its customers donating just over £4million.

pages.headline: Police station cleared after woman strolls in with a grenade
pages.teaser: COPS called in Army to remove the Second World War-era explosive weapon
pages.articlebody:
A POLICE station was evacuated and a bomb disposal unit called after a woman brought in a HAND GRANADE.

She told officers the weapon, which dated back to the Second World War, was once owned by a relative.

Hampshire Police called for support from the Army after the device was taken into Alton police station last night.

The grenade, which contained explosive material, was safely removed.

A police spokesman said: "A member of the public attended the police station with a World War Two hand grenade.

"The area was secured by local officers while specialist advice was sought and then following this advice the Army attended.

"The grenade was then removed by an Explosive Ordnance Disposal unit.

"Although the risk to the public was low the grenade was found to contain an amount of explosives."

pages.subdeck: Tragic ... one bus passenger was killed in the crash
pages.headline: Bus driver arrested as 1 person dies and 40 are injured in M5 crash
pages.teaser: BUS driver is arrested on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving
pages.articlebody:
A PASSENGER was killed and 40 others injured - two critically - in a horror crash involving a bus and a lorry this morning.

Police said the bus had broken down in the slow lane of the M5 in the West Midlands when a lorry crashed into the back of it at around 6.30am.

This afternoon, the 49-year-old driver of the bus, from Birmingham, was arrested on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving.

A 35-year-old man from Birmingham died at the scene of the crash.

Images from the scene showed an articulated lorry branded with Fowler-Welch Coolchain embedded into the rear nearside edge of a single-decker bus.

Several ambulances and other rescue vehicles were sent to the scene on the southbound carriageway between junctions three and four.

West Midlands Ambulance Service said 40 people had been assessed and treated at the scene, and 27 were taken to four different hospitals around the region.

A spokesman said: "While the majority of patients appear to be walking wounded there are a small number with potentially serious injuries."

West Midlands Police said no children had been involved in the accident and confirmed that the driver of the lorry was among those seriously injured.

The affected stretch of the M5 is likely to remain closed in both directions for a considerable time and motorists are being advised to find alternative routes.

Eyewitness Paul Guppy said there were patches of heavy fog on the motorway at the time of the crash.

He said: "There were fog patches, because I was driving through it with my fog lights on. That area is renowned for having fog, there's a lot of low-lying land.

"It was quite horrendous at the time, and then it cleared. Whether the fog was a contributory thing, I don't know."

The bus seemed to have been hit from the rear and was leaning virtually intact against a crash barrier, he added.

Artwork on the side of the bus shows Laurel and Hardy with the words "This is another fine bus you've gotten me into" - a reference to the comedy duo's famous catchphrase.

It is branded with the livery of bus company Stagecoach, but the vehicle had been sold by the company to a dealer 18 months ago. The vehicle was taking local workers to Evesham, Worcs.

Penny Morgan told how she phoned 999 after swerving to avoid it minutes before the early morning smash near Junction 3, close to Halesowen. She said of the fog: "You couldn't see your hand in front of you."

When the bus broke down the Highways Agency lit up electronic sign warnings saying: "Incident, slow down."

pages.subdeck: Tears for her hero ... Christina Schmid recalls fateful day her husband Staff Sergeant Olaf died
pages.headline: War widow predicted death
pages.teaser: WIDOW reveals spooky premonitions in book about her husband Sgt Olaf Schmid
pages.articlebody:
WAR widow Christina Schmid read her hero husband's Tarot cards before his fateful tour  with nightmare results.

The burning Tower card, seen as the harbinger of doom, repeatedly cropped up.

It was one of a host of spooky premonitions she had both before and during hubby Oz's fatal five-month mission to the Afghanistan front line, where he defused 70 Taliban bombs.

Today Christina tells of the dreadful day he begged her to read his future  and the moment she saw his destruction in the cards.

In her own words, taken from her memoir about Staff Sergeant Olaf "Oz" Schmid, Always By My Side, she writes: "Oz asked me to do his Tarot cards.

"The Tarot was something I did very rarely, perhaps once every other year. I wasn't sure about doing it this time, but Oz urged me to and I agreed.

"I had done them since I was young and I seemed to be gifted. The card he chose to show the future was the Burning Tower. I did them again, this time for career, Oz chose the Burning Tower again. The worst card there is.

"It signifies death and endings, the worst outcome imaginable and entirely unavoidable. Everything you know gone in ruin or catastrophe.

Oz looked stricken. He said, 'I feel this is going to be a really bad year for me. I've got this feeling as if everything is slipping'.

"I tried to lighten it, saying, 'You'll probably just stub your toe when you're at work  you're always a screamer with loads of bad luck! Don't worry, it might just mean that you won't get a promotion or something'.

"'No', he said. 'It's not the card. That just confirmed what I already know and feel'.

"When it was my turn to choose a card I hoped I might get something that would lift the mood, but I was startled when I got it in my spread of cards, too.

"But then I got rebirth after, and the moon. 'See, hun  always light in the dark. Remember that', he said. I tried to hide my dismay. 'It's a dark time of year. Perhaps we're both just feeling it', I said.

" 'Let's be positive, forget the cards, we've got lots to look forward to', I chirped, waiting for him to follow my lead.

"He usually did, but this time Oz said, 'No, it's bad. I've got this feeling that if I go out after January or February, I'm not coming back. That's what my gut is telling me'. There was nothing I could say that would cheer him and the truth was it was hard even to try, because I felt worried too."

Despite the omen, devoted Christina put aside her foreboding when Oz was sent to the front.

During his dangerous deployment she would make a wish for his protection during the full moon.

But on the last full moon before Oz's return she inexplicably fell asleep with young son Laird and missed her routine.

She writes: "I woke around 4am, disorientated. I was fully clothed and Laird was asleep on me, in his pyjamas. As the realisation dawned that I had missed doing the wish for Oz, the moon had disappeared and I felt distraught.

" 'Oh my God, what have I done?' I whispered. 'I've done it every month. Why now?'

"I told myself it didn't matter, that it was just a bit of silly tradition, that I should forget it. But I couldn't."

Christina's foreboding grew to fever pitch shortly before Oz, who won a gallantry gong on his tour, was due home.

The spooky signs grew to the point where she says she KNEW he was dead even before the fateful news came with a knock on the door from two officers bringing confirmation.

She writes: "Two days before he was due to leave Afghanistan for home, Oz called again. I could hear immediately that he was low.

"He had been out of contact for several days and he sounded shattered. He said, 'Honey, I just feel really bad, I've got this odd feeling, like dread, I don't feel safe, it's bad. Have you got it too?' I had. In the pit of my stomach I felt a lurch as he spoke.

"I had been uneasy, anxious, and had a feeling of dread, but I didn't want to say that.

'You're tired,' I said. 'It's OK, you'll be back soon. Do what you did the last few months in the next couple of days, hun. You've got 48 hours left, that's all'.

" 'Honey', he said, 'I'm mentally and spiritually hammered, I'm hanging out. I've been away too long, worked too much.

" 'And if it's too much for me it's too much for anyone. But I can't let it show. I've got to keep positive and strong, they (the other men) have to trust me. If anything happens to me, I don't want them to blame themselves.

" 'I wish you could come and get me. I need you. Just come and get me now, honey'.

" 'I wish I could', I said, tears running down my face. 'But I can't. You've got to stop talking like this, you're just tired. You can push for 48 hours'. 'I need to speak to Laird,' he said. I handed Laird the phone and he went upstairs and they talked.

"When Laird gave the phone back, Oz said, 'I'm calm, honey, but I can't help how I feel. I don't think I'm coming back, 'cos I'm cuffing it now. I'm drained  it's hard to explain'.

"The next day I kept the phone beside me all evening, hoping he'd ring. I wanted to ring him but I couldn't, so that night I emailed  'Please email me, Don't go out on the ground tomorrow, cut the last day, don't do it.' He never got it."

That night Christina had a visitation in her dreams from another hero bomb hunter, Warrant Officer Gary "Gaz" O'Donnell, who had perished in the Afghan badlands disarming a Taliban device.

She writes: "I slept fitfully then I dreamed that Gaz O'Donnell was standing in front of me. 'Don't worry, Chris, I'm here to get him when he comes over,' he said. 'I'll hold him. I won't let go'.

" 'What are you on about?' I said. 'You've got no arms'. Gaz just looked at me and smiled.

"The next morning, Saturday October 31, 2009, I woke at 6.30am with a feeling I'd never had before. It was as powerful as thunder.

" 'It's today', I thought. 'He's going or has he gone yet?' I felt it so surely that it was in the floor beneath my feet as I got out of bed and in the air around me as I went downstairs.

"I felt numb, suspended in time, as I went through the motions of life. At nine I phoned my mum and told her I wasn't going to take Laird to his swimming lesson that morning. 'What's going on?' she said. 'You sound so quiet. Oz is home tomorrow, you should be happy'.

"I paused. 'He's not coming home, Mum, I know it'. "

Oz was killed, defusing a bomb, on Halloween while Christina was walking in the woods gathering her thoughts.

At the exact moment he died she wept uncontrollably.

Later in her book Christina reveals more spiritual happenings. She tells how Oz's spirit communicated with her through the spiritualist mum of a friend.

She writes what the spiritualist said: "He's saying, 'Coffee, white, one  man-up'. Oh, and what an awful taste, it's something like liquorice. What is that?' I smiled. 'His liquorice rollies, the menthol tips, he always smoked them. And that's how he talked'. She had his intonation exactly right.

"She always passes on an Oz message in his distinctive style.

"And it helps me to keep going and keeps me grounded."

d.willetts@the-sun.co.uk

pages.teaser: PRIME Minster's 40p unit minimum for booze has been slammed by backbenchers
pages.articlebody:
DAVID Cameron's war on binge drinkers was slammed by his backbenchers last night.

The backlash came as drinks firms threatened a legal challenge over the PM's idea that alcohol should be sold for a minimum 40p per unit  saying it breaches EU law.

It would end "buy one get one free" booze offers and set high-strength lager at a minimum £1.20 a canand set see a two-litre bottle of 9 per cent cider rise from £3 to £7.20.

Tory Philip Davies accused the PM of "living in cloud cuckoo land" to believe it will stem rowdy teen boozing.

He said as Home Secretary Theresa May unveiled the policy yesterday: "It's the nanny state running riot."

Conservative Therese Coffey said it could harm families who have to "budget carefully". And colleague Nigel Mills claimed more booze would be smuggled to the UK.

Furious drinks firms insisted the 40p tariff broke competition rules.

The Wine and Spirit Trade Association said last night: "Minimum pricing is illegal under European laws."

Labour's Eric Joyce, who drunkenly assaulted MPs in a Commons bar, said he was also against minimum pricing. He admitted on BBC's Newsnight: "This has no impact on people like me."

pages.articlebody:
KAZAKHSTAN'S sport stars were left in shock after their national anthem was replaced at a medal ceremony  by the spoof version from movie comedy Borat.

The side-splitting ditty from Sacha Baron Cohen's hit flick includes the lines "Kazakhstan's prostitutes cleanest in region" and calls other nations "run by little girls".

It was mistakenly played at a ceremony for the central Asian nation's shooting team in Kuwait.

Footage from the presentation shows confused gold medallist Maria Dmitrienko listening to the anthem before grinning.

The Kazakh team's coach revealed organisers accidentally downloaded the wrong anthem from the net.

Borat's parody also brags: "Kazakhstan  Number One exporter of potassium," adding: "We invented toffee and trouser belt". It invites foes to: "Come grasp the mighty penis of our leader."

The music gaffe was the second to hit Kazakhstan's sports stars this month. Ricky Martin's 1999 No 1 hit Livin' La Vida Loca was played instead of the country's official anthem called "My Kazakhstan" at a skiing event on their own soil weeks earlier.

pages.articlebody:
NOT a vote has been cast and already the Tories have managed to get taxes down.

Labour's surrender on 10 per cent extra cider duty is a triumph for David Cameron.

The Tories also blocked Labour's planned broadband tax.

Not a bad start as the Tories were clear winners on Day One of the election campaign.

In the Commons, Mr Cameron exposed Gordon Brown's weasel words over Labour's jobs tax.

Mr Brown says the business world has been deceived by the Tories into thinking that Labour's National Insurance tax rise will cost jobs.

Business leaders say Mr Brown is patronising, "economically illiterate" and insults their intelligence.

Almost seventy of Britain's biggest employers  including one of Mr Brown's own advisers  say the Tories are RIGHT.

The Sun agrees. Making firms pay more in tax for every person hired means bosses take on fewer workers.

Only in the warped world of Gordon Brown does raising National Insurance help unemployment.

The fed-up business community has washed its hands of union-run Labour.

Employers think that there will be more REAL jobs under the Tories.

Exactly what the country needs to hear.

Blaze heroes

FIREMEN didn't hesitate when they arrived at a blazing block of high-rise flats.

They plunged straight in  and two tragically lost their lives.

The Sun pays tribute to Hampshire fire heroes James Shears and Alan Bannon.

The brave men and women of our emergency services are very special.

When it comes to the crunch, they lay their lives on the line for us.

We are very lucky. We should be grateful and never forget their sacrifice.

Brave champ

TENNIS ace Martina Navratilova faces another tough challenge.

The legendary champ is diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 53.

Not even a superfit athlete like Martina is safe from a cancer that affects women indiscriminately.

Many Sun readers will have a relative or friend who has been struck down.

Cancer survival rates in Britain have improved over the years. But they lag behind much of Europe and America, where Martina is optimistic about her prospects.

Yes, times are tough. But our next Government must do much more to improve our record on survival rates for breast and other cancers.

Brave Martina, who never gave up on court, will not give up on this fight either.

pages.headline: Former Russian banker shot
pages.teaser: GERMAN Gorbuntsov in critical condition after being shot near Canary Wharf, east London
pages.byline: By ANTHONY FRANCE and RYAN SABEY
pages.articlebody:
A RUSSIAN banking tycoon was in a coma last night after he was gunned down outside his London flat by a "drive-by" hitman.

Exiled financier German Gorbuntsov, 45, fell in a hail of sub-machine gun bullets fired by the would-be assassin.

Blood was smeared all over the walls of the lobby of his exclusive apartment block and the bullets also took out chunks of the front door and smashed windows.

One witness to the terrifying shooting near the Canary Wharf financial district said Gorbuntsov seemed to be targeted by a drive-by gunman.

Bart Fogler, 27, who works on the front desk of a nearby block, said: "I heard from a resident the shots may have come from a car.

"I ran next door where I saw the shot man and his wife who was hysterical. I saw holes in his clothes.

"He was bleeding heavily. He was trying to stand but he fell to the ground."

Resident Lynette Johnson, 43  who saw the lobby after the shooting  said: "There was blood everywhere, all over the walls.

"The windows were smashed so he may have been shot through them."

Gorbuntsov  who used to own banks in Russia and Moldova  was last night under armed police guard in hospital where he was said to be critical but stable. His coma is medically induced.

It is thought he may have been targeted after he was named as a witness in the shooting of a Russian banker in Moscow in 2009.

He had apparently told his lawyer: "If I go back to Russia, they will kill me."

One neighbour last night said police told him Gorbuntsov knew the hitman.

The 54-year-old  who did not want to be named  said: "They mentioned that the attacker was known to the man who was attacked."

Former Kremlin adviser Aleksander Nekrassov said: "It looks like a contract hit because a sub-machine gun is not a weapon that would be used by some amateur."

The Met's Trident gang crime team were last night probing Tuesday evening's shooting in Byng Street, East London, which they are treating as attempted murder.

a.france@the-sun.co.uk

Pro killers on streets



THE attempted assassination of Russian Gorbuntsov is not the first time hitmen have struck in Britain.

In 2006 ex-KGB dissident Alexander Litvinenko, 41, was poisoned with radioactive polonium in London.

Russian authorities have refused to extradite the prime suspect, fellow former agent Andrei Lugovoy.

MI6 agent Gareth Williams, 31, was mysteriously found dead in a bag at his flat in Pimlico, South London, in August 2010. A couple seen there weeks earlier have never been traced.

And one of the most famous assassinations saw Bulgarian dissident Georgi Markov, 49, killed by ricin poison delivered by a pellet embedded in the end of a brolly on Waterloo Bridge in 1978.

The crime was never officially solved but years later two ex-KGB men said the Soviets were behind it.

pages.teaser: A HERO coach driver saved the life of a girl passenger after she had an epileptic fit and stopped breathing
pages.articlebody:
A HERO coach driver saved the life of a girl passenger after she had an epileptic fit and stopped breathing.

Phil Forster, 48, pulled over into a lay-by and performed CPR on Nicolle Marshall, 19, as she turned blue in front of terrified pals.

As he battled to revive the sick teen, his wife May, 51  on board as co-driver  leapt behind the wheel and drove the coach to meet an ambulance.

Phil  who is a St John Ambulance-trained first aider  saved laundry worker Nicolle as he drove fans of ice hockey team the Solway Sharks to a match in Sheffield.

The driver, from Carlisle, said: "We were on the A66 when one of Nicolle's friends said she had stopped breathing.

"I pulled over immediately and started doing chest compressions.

"She coughed and started breathing again.

"Someone had phoned for an ambulance so I said to May it would be quicker if she drove to Scotch Corner. We got there before the medics."

Nicolle  who has made a full recovery  had a chance to thank Phil and May when they drove her to another Solway Sharks fixture last week. The teenager, of Dumfries, said: "I thanked them for all they did. I can't really remember the coach trip at all."

Solway Sharks secretary David Morrison  who was on the coach  said: "Phil's fast actions were amazing. I have no doubt he saved Nicolle's life. He and May were both quite superb."

It is the second time Phil  a coach driver for 12 years and a trained first aider for five  has saved a life. Five months ago he revived 18-month-old Jessica Howard after she choked on a grape in a supermarket.

He said: "It's all down to the training I've had."

pages.teaser: BRITAIN'S biggest brands are going on a "diet"  slashing their calorie count as part of a war on obesity
pages.byline: By EMMA LITTLE, Health Editor and DANIEL JONES, Consumer Editor
pages.articlebody:
BRITAIN'S biggest brands are going on a "diet"  slashing their calorie count as part of a war on obesity.

The number of calories in certain products made by soft drinks giant Coca-Cola will be cut by 30 per cent by 2014.

It will also pump more cash into marketing Diet Coke and Coca-Cola Zero, which contain no sugar, and increase their availability.

Mars bars will be cut from 300 calories to 250, and super-size "Grab Bags" of Walkers crisps, containing 263 calories, will be phased out and replaced with 185-calorie packs.

The move aims to take FIVE BILLION calories a day off Britain's national food and drink intake. More than two-thirds of adults and one in three 11-year-olds are now overweight or obese. Food manufacturers, supermarkets, pubs and caterers joined with the Department of Health yesterday to announce the "Responsibility Deal".

Producers including Hovis and Mr Kipling will slash calorie counts by 30 per cent across a third of their ranges.

Supermarkets will expand their healthy meal ranges and sandwich chain Subway will include five low-fat subs in its £3 lunch offer. Health Secretary Andrew Lansley hailed the plan as "a great step in the right direction," adding: "We all have a role to play."

Diet expert Dr Susan Jebb, of Cambridge University, said: "This programme is vital to tackle obesity. It's a very encouraging start, but it will take time to change the nation's eating habits."

She said she wanted to make sure Qatada's deportation cannot be reversed before acting.

pages.headline: I'm proud my brother killed kids
pages.teaser: CHILLING comments come after Mohammed Merah kills seven people in massacre
pages.byline: By NICK PARKER, Chief Foreign Correspondent
pages.articlebody:
THE brother of the al-Qaeda maniac who massacred seven people including three kids has said he is proud of the killing spree.

Abdelkader Merah, 29, was arrested as cops cornered crazed Mohammed, 23, in his flat and shot him dead.

The older brother is also linked to militant Islamic groups and is being held over alleged terror offences with his girlfriend and mother.

He told cops: "I am very proud of my brother. I regret nothing for him and approve of what he did."

His chilling comments came as new pictures were released yesterday of Thursday's raid in Toulouse in which Merah was gunned down by French special forces. Four cops were wounded during the 32-hour siege and one was shown being stretchered away.

Officials last night said an autopsy on Merah showed he died of two bullet wounds to the head and stomach  but was hit by 20 bullets, mainly in the arms and legs.

The terrorist staged a bloodbath at a Jewish school on Monday  killing a teacher, his sons aged five and three and the head's daughter aged eight. The week before he killed three off-duty soldiers.

Police believe Abdelkader may have known about his terror plans.

The brothers were involved in a militant network known as the Toulouse group which allegedly hatched a plot to attack a shopping centre in the city.

French PM Francois Fillon yesterday defended security agencies who left self-confessed alQaeda terrorist Merah at large to kill. He said: "There was no single element to allow for his detention."

Meanwhile, an English teacher sparked outrage across France yesterday after calling for her pupils to observe a minute's silence for "unhappy" Merah. There were calls for Lorraine Collin, 56, to be suspended from her high school job in Rouen.

- EUROPEAN security officials yesterday warned of the growing danger of home-grown Islamic militants who act independently of known terror networks.

pages.teaser: A MEMO advising the PM on how to talk to freed British hostage Judith Tebbutt was found at a railway station
pages.articlebody:
A MEMO advising the PM on how to talk to freed British hostage Judith Tebbutt was found at a railway station.

An aide to David Cameron dropped the "script" as he got off a train at Leeds on Thursday.

Hours later he was due to chat to kidnap victim Judith, 56, on the phone.

The memo, addressed to the Premier, offers detailed points from the Foreign Office on what to say.

One suggests he should remark: "I am delighted to be able to speak with you, Judith. I cannot imagine what you have experienced over the past six months.

"I have closely followed your ordeal from the outset and I am thankful you have been released safely."

Another mentions Judith's son Oliver, 25, who organised a reported £800,000 ransom payment to the Somali pirates who snatched her. They shot dead her husband David, 58, in a raid last year on a resort in Kenya.

The memo suggests the PM should tell her: "Please accept my condolences on the tragic death of your husband."

Judith, of Bishop's Stortford, Herts, landed at Heathrow Airport last night.

It appears Mr Cameron kept to his script. On Thursday he told factory staff at her hometown of Ulverston, Cumbria, that he found her "courageous, brave and resolute" during their telephone conversion.

A source said: "If she finds out the conversation was pretty much scripted then I can't imagine she will be very impressed."

The PM's spokeswoman insisted the memo had "no sensitive information".

FURIOUS Roberto Mancini refused to shake Tony Pulis' hand after a bitter elbow row last night.

Mancini watched his Manchester City side drop two priceless points in the title race after being held at Stoke.

Along with assistant David Platt he was seething at the rough-house tactics which left David Silva with a cut ear following a clash with Dean Whitehead.

Mancini blanked the post-match Press conference and Platt revealed: "He is not happy. He's worried he might say soemthing that gets him in hot water. It was really about the way the game unfolded.

"It's very intense and all he said was: 'You better go up because I don't trust myself.'

"There's not much point in me coming up and having a go at the referee.

"I know David Silva has a cut on his ear but I haven't seen it and I wouldn't accuse the player."

Platt confronted referee Howard Webb at the final whistle, while Mancini stepped on to the pitch to avoid a handshake with Potters boss Pulis.

Silva needed lengthy treatment following the Whitehead clash and returned to the pitch with his head heavily bandaged and there were a number of other challenges that riled Mancini.

Asked about Mancini's refusal to shake hands, Pulis said: "Mancini has got to do what has to do."

pages.headline: Fab wished us luck
pages.teaser: OWEN COYLE has revealed that a private message from Fabrice Muamba inspired Bolton's basement-battle victory
pages.articlebody:
OWEN COYLE says a private message from Fabrice Muamba inspired Bolton's basement-battle victory.

Midfielder Muamba, in intensive care following his cardiac arrest at Spurs last week, wished his team-mates good luck for Saturday's emotional visit from Blackburn.

And David Wheater netted two goals for the first time in his career as the Trotters beat their in-form drop rivals 2-1 to move out of the bottom three.

Bolton boss Coyle said: "Fabrice managed to send us a message yesterday through one of the consultants to say he wished the lads well.

"It was great when we heard that.

"Our chairman has been in touch with (Fabrice's dad) Marcel this week and I am pretty sure the information about today's game has been passed on to Fabrice."

Coyle expects Marcel and Muamba's fiancee Shauna to tell the popular star, 23, that the Trotters are now on course to stay up.

The Bolton chief declined to say what words his team exchanged as they huddled together in victory.

He said: "It is a private thing. I wanted to thank everybody for their efforts.

"It has been an emotional week and the players were out on their feet at the end, both physically and mentally.

"But that is a small thing compared to the fight Fabrice has got."

Coyle added: "The team talk wasn't long today. Nothing is more important to us than Fabrice.

"If he is able to recover and have a great life with Shauna and his son Josh, that will be fantastic.

"But, God willing, he is able to play football again at this level, and if it is, our aim is for him to do that as a Premier League player."

Blackburn boss Steve Kean, who was equally dignified, said: "I told the lads to separate the occasion from the game.

"We wish Fabrice all the goodwill we can give but we had to play the match.

"The Bolton players had a spring in their step and once they got their noses in front it was difficult."

CHELSEA owner Roman Abramovich has ruled out an emotional return for Jose Mourinho.

The Special One, who secured six trophies in three seasons at Stamford Bridge, has refused to rule out quitting Real Madrid in the summer and completing what he claims is unfinished business at SW6.

But billionaire Red Rom, who forked out nearly £16million in compensation to Mourinho when they parted company in 2007, insists he will not come back.

SunSport exclusively revealed on Friday the Blues owner is ready to offer Barcelona boss Pep Guardiola a whopping four-year deal worth £40MILLION after tax in a bid to tempt him from the Nou Camp.

A highly placed Blues source said: "There is absolutely no way Roman will go back in for Jose  no way.

"Russians never go back, they replace things rather than fix them and they never admit they are wrong.

"For Roman to bring back Mourinho would be admitting to a very expensive mistake."

Abramovich was also said to be furious last month when Mourinho was house-hunting in London  and it was conveniently leaked at a time when the pressure on Chelsea boss Andre Villas-Boas had reached breaking point.

The source added: "It's convenient that Jose is always talking up a return when there are problems at other clubs. The same problems eventually led to his departure.

"While Roman continues to own the club people should forget about him returning."

pages.subdeck: USED CAR ... Fergie with Tevez at United, before the Argy jumped ship to City
pages.headline: You're wrong about Tev, Fergie
pages.teaser: ROY KEANE says it is not desperate to bring Tev back  it is good management
pages.articlebody:
ALEX FERGUSON is wrong to call Carlos Tevez's return an act of desperation. It's called good management.

Manchester United have more to lose than City do with Tevez coming back because Ferguson will know full well that he is the sort of player who can turn tight games in his side's favour If he wasn't worried about City, would he even be talking about them?

Already, we have seen how Tevez set up the winner for Samir Nasri in City's 2-1 win over Chelsea on Wednesday at a time when they needed a spark.

You don't cut off your nose to spite your face and when you've a good player like Tevez you'd be crazy not to use him.

OK, Roberto Mancini had to be careful not to lose face in a situation where he had said Tevez would never play for the club again after he had refused to go on as a substitute.

But once Tevez apologised why wouldn't you bring him back? Ferguson is wrong, it's not desperation, just common sense.

Does he believe that Tevez should really never play for City again just because Mancini said he wouldn't after he refused to go on the pitch at Bayern Munich?

Ferguson has been around long enough to know things change and if you're going to apply those high standards then you had better make sure you are consistent.

Remember it was only last September that Paul Scholes revealed that he had refused to play for United in a League Cup tie against Arsenal in 2001.

There was no question at the time of Scholesy's United career being over even though he later admitted that what he had done was as bad  if not worse  than Tevez's actions.

You have to move on in football. Things happen in the heat of the moment but if people are calm and reasonable they can be worked out.

It might have suited United if Tevez didn't play for City for the rest of the season because he is a talent who increases their attacking options.

And Ferguson will be fully aware of Tevez's capabilities having worked with him at United.

He might have allowed him to leave Old Trafford but that doesn't mean he didn't rate him as a player.

He wouldn't have appreciated his carry-on when he tried to put pressure on him to give him a new contract but he will be aware of what an asset is he is on the pitch.

The fact that he made such a quick impact on his return to the fold will quell any discontent the City fans might feel about his behaviour and he has a role to play in the run-in.

He might not start but he doesn't need to because he reminds me of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer in his ability to get up to speed in a game almost as soon as he came on.

Remember that was his first game in five months and he still made his mark. Adrenaline could carry him through until the end of the season even if his fitness is not completely up to the mark.

The only reason Ferguson felt the need to have a pop at Tevez was because the mind games have started, the sure sign a title race has entered the title straight.

Once Patrick Vieira said bringing back Scholes was an act of desperation, he was always going to react.

That's what he does, defend his club and his players. I think he gets a buzz off it.

Some sports people like Muhammad Ali and Usain Bolt thrive off being in the headlines and creating them and I think Ferguson is the same.

In years gone by, we've seen him lock horns with Arsenal, Liverpool and Newcastle but this is a different ball game because the challenge is right on his doorstep.

He tried to put them down as 'noisy neighbours' before but City have kept coming and got stronger and stronger.

United feel threatened, there's no doubt about that.

In the past, Ferguson has got into rows with Arsene Wenger, Rafa Benitez and Kevin Keegan but the key is that his side have always been able to back him up.

United have walked the walk after he talked the talk so he hasn't been left with egg on his face.

Wouldn't it be a desperate irony if what he said about a former player came back to haunt him when the two sides meet on April 30?

Don't be so Kean

STEVE KEAN is getting a lot of plaudits right now  and, on the face of it, things have taken a turn for the better at Blackburn Rovers.

Three months ago, Blackburn were rooted to the foot of the table and the local paper and MP had both called on him to quit.

That's not to mention the fans whose opposition was so aggressive that he had hired a bodyguard.

Things have improved a bit in the meantime.

A run of five wins and three draws in 12 games has seen them climb off the foot of the table to 16th.

They are a full five points clear of the relegation zone and seem to have a bit of momentum that other sides have lacked. That is despite having to work under difficult circumstances.

His best player, Chris Samba, decided he did not want to play and was sold to Russian side Anzi after the English transfer window shut.

But can we actually say he is doing well just because they are no longer in the bottom three?

To me, it looks like Kean might be helped by the fact that other sides are not as competitive as in previous years.

Wolves and Wigan have taken just 22 points and Bolton only a point more. At the same stage last season, the bottom three  Wigan, Wolves and West Ham  had 27, 29 and 31 points respectively.

It is more a case of them not doing as badly as other teams.

And because he started off with people having such a low opinion of him, it seems like he is a no-lose situation.

If Blackburn do badly, people did not expect anything else and if they do OK, it's a bonus.

Still, not many would have expected him to turn it around as he has, so all credit to him for that.

pages.subdeck: OXING CLEVER ... Alex has proved a top buy for Arsenal
pages.headline: Ox can be our Roo
pages.teaser: TEEN sensation Alex has announced himself at the top level in style this year
pages.articlebody:
ROBIN VAN PERSIE has tipped Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain to be Arsenal's answer to Wayne Rooney.

The Ox has burst on to the scene with impressive displays this season  including a starring role in the Gunners' 3-0 Champions League win over AC Milan.

That performance saw the winger compared with Manchester United ace Rooney, who shot to world fame when he became the youngest player to score in European Championship history in 2004.

Arsenal boss Arsene Wenger has already said he believes Chamberlain, 18, is destined to gatecrash England's squad for this summer's tournament in Poland and Ukraine.

And Gunners skipper Van Persie has backed the teenager to have the same effect as Rooney.

The Dutchman said: "Alex can have a big impact. He has everything you need, I'm sure he has a bright future for Arsenal and England.

"He's shown that already in a couple of games.

"He has pace, he is clever, knows when to pass, when to keep the ball and has good technique.

"He's a bit like Rooney, who I rate highly. Rooney's a big player and a good all-rounder who can score goals, provide assists and make nice runs  he has a bit of everything.

"And although Alex plays on the left or right  whereas Rooney plays more through the middle  that could change in the future. They are both good all-round players."

Van Persie is the man currently firing the Gunners to glory.

This season has been his best in an Arsenal shirt with 33 goals to his name already but the 28-year-old Holland ace credits his team-mates and Wenger for making his scoring heroics possible.

He added: "I've been working with Arsene Wenger for eight years now and he's been a big influence on me, together with the team and the club.

"That's everyone from the kitman to the manager  they all help each other. Lots of my achievements are down to the rest of the players because, without them, I'm nothing.

"I'm not doing anything differently  I still love to play football and train but for the last 18 months I've been able to play week in, week out. You can see the results.

"Hopefully, I can stay in this form and keep it going."

Van Persie's scoring exploits have made him a frontrunner with bookies for this season's Player-of-the-Year accolade.

But he joked: "I've paid them off! We'll see. It would be special if I was picked as a candidate but that's for later."

pages.subdeck: UP IN ARMS ... Roberto Mancini cuts a frustrated figure at the Stadium of Light
pages.headline: Is Mancini cracking up?
pages.teaser: ROBERTO MANCINI could not trust himself to speak publicly after dropping two priceless points in the title race
pages.articlebody:
ROBERTO MANCINI could not trust himself to speak publicly after losing two priceless points in the title race.

Yes, he could point to Stoke's physical approach and whinge that his players had not had enough protection from ref Howard Webb.

Yes, he could claim that David Silva was the victim of a flying elbow and Mario Balotelli had been hauled down by an arm wrapped around his face.

But the truth is that the title heat is really getting to the volatile Italian.

The Manchester City manager erupted in fury on the day title rival  Manchester United boss Alex Ferguson  warned him he may not be able to handle Squeaky Bum Time.

It also came after a build-up which saw Fergie accuse Mancini of desperation for playing Carlos Tevez last week and which saw United star Rio Ferdinand claim City's fans had "come out of the woodwork" this season.

Yaya Toure's late strike cancelled out a Peter Crouch wonder goal to rescue City a draw at the Britannia Stadium and send them back to the top of the Premier League on goal difference.

But City have now won just two of their last nine away games and could fall three points behind Manchester United if the Reds beat Fulham tomorrow.

However, Mancini's defiant assistant David Platt says Fergie has not won the mind games war, insisting: "What are mind games?

"The team which wins the League will be said to have won the mind games.

"The be all and end all is about 11 players going out on the pitch and getting results. Words don't win leagues.

"I'm happy with the performance and Roberto is happy with it.

"People will say it's two points lost, but if we win the Premier League by a point it might be this point.

"The reason we're not pulling away is down to the fact United are having a good season."

Crouch scored a stunning volley before Yaya Toure levelled with a deflected drive. And Toure declared: "It's important not to panic. It is always difficult to play Stoke and the important thing is to work hard and believe in ourselves.

"We didn't deserve more than a draw today  Stoke played well.

"We gave ourselves problems, but it's important to keep going and wait until Monday, to see what United do."

His brother Kolo added: "It's always difficult here. We are disappointed to have dropped two points but it's still a good result. Every point is valuable."

Crouch's goal will live long in the memory as he teed up the ball with his right foot and delivered an incredible angled volley from wide outside the area.

He said: "I knew as soon as it left my foot I had a good chance. I was really pleased with the manner of the goal, it has to be up there with one of the best I've scored.

"I always enjoy volleying the ball in training but I don't get many like that. The lads will tell you I work on it every day, but it doesn't always pay off in games. It was great to see it fly in."

Crouch is now hoping to force his way back into the England squad for the Euro 2012 finals.

He added: "The aim has always been to do well for Stoke and hopefully get in the England set-up. I've been fortunate enough to play for my country a number of times and enjoyed every minute.

"I love playing here, they play to my strengths. The lads and the gaffer have been brilliant."

Pulis said: "It was a very good game. Crouch's goal was fantastic. He does that in training. It's not just a one-off and technically he's a gifted young man."

pages.subdeck: STRIKING ... forward Sturridge has ambition
pages.headline: I should play instead of Drogba 'n Torres
pages.teaser: AND once he is top man at Chelsea, 'Studge' is certain he can be England's No1, too
pages.articlebody:
DANIEL STURRIDGE is an extremely self-assured young man. In fact, a more confident person would be difficult to find.

Too cocky, too selfish and with way too much swagger, some would say.

But, trust me, "Studge" will not budge.

He has a rock-solid focus on what he wants and where he wants to go.

Which is to the very top  with Chelsea and with England.

That is why he believes...

  • He can replace Wayne Rooney for England at Euro 2012.

  • He should play instead of Didier Drogba and Fernando Torres at Chelsea.

  • He will win silverware with the Blues this season.

  • It would be madness for him to change.

    His critics will say that is precisely his problem: too full of himself and too blinkered to others.

    But not our Daniel. He insists that is his strength.

    And sitting with him, listening to him, debating with him... you tend to agree.

    For here is a man who dares to be different, someone who will do it his way or die trying and you cannot help but admire that.

    Asked to describe himself, he replied: "I am young and free-thinking with new ideas and a new positivity.

    "I am an attacking player. I am young and fresh and I want to prove myself.

    "I am someone who is trying to champion a new way of playing  in my team, in my national team and in my career."

    See, told you he was not shy in coming forward.

    But there's more.

    Like his attitude to replacing the suspended Rooney in Poland and Ukraine.

    He added: "That's not going to faze me at all.

    "You only have one football career and in 10 years' time I don't want to look back and be depressed because I didn't achieve my targets. So I believe I can do it.

    "Wayne Rooney is obviously a world-class player, everyone knows that. But the one thing that's always driven me on is that desire to succeed, to be the best I can be. So I would love the opportunity."

    He might just get it.

    Sturridge was voted man of the match for England against the Netherlands at Wembley last month, despite coming on only as a first-half substitute and then hobbling off injured before the end.

    Ecstasy and agony in the same memorable moment.

    He recalled: "I was having a needle prodded into my toe at the time.

    "It was the Chelsea osteopath who told me I had got man of the match and I sort of snapped, 'Do you mind? I'm in a lot of pain right now'.

    "I just didn't believe him and it wasn't until I was leaving the stadium and was asked to do an interview that I realised it was true. Obviously, I was very pleased. They were my first serious minutes as an England player and I had done well at Wembley in front of so many great fans. That's a dream for every player.

    "And you can be sure I won't be opening that bottle of champagne, that's one for the mantelpiece  I just wish I had got it signed."

    Sturridge had a face like thunder when he was subbed for Fernando Torres in the thrilling Champions League win over Napoli the other night.

    And he would have been miserable consigned to the bench in this week's 2-1 loss at former club Manchester City.

    He has nothing personal against £50million Torres, nor Drogba for that matter.

    Studge just wants to be the main man down the middle for Chelsea.

    He insisted: "That's the position I will always pick myself, centre-forward."

    And added, less convincingly: "But whatever position the manager picks me in I'm happy and right now, for the team, I'm in the wide position.

    "I will always give 100 per cent and work as hard as I can to get the success we all want."

    Sturridge is used to battling for recognition and respect since his early days growing up in the Jewellery Quarter of Birmingham. He said: "I grew up in Hockley and was always surrounded by older kids and grown-ups.

    "My brother is older than me and I was always playing with him and his friends.

    "I was never in my own age group. I was always with the older lads but I didn't feel shy around them or inferior. I wasn't scared playing against them. I just wanted to prove myself.

    "Even then I wanted to be the best I could be. I was always trying to improve, to learn. I think that's what's given me so much confidence now in my own ability.

    "And that's why I will always try to express myself, even if I'm feeling less confident because I'm maybe having a bad patch.

    "Because I know everyone has bad times in every job, in everyone's life.

    "Everything doesn't run as smoothly as you would like all the time. So you have to persevere, believe and work as hard as you can to change what you are going through, to stay grounded and fully focused."

    That is especially true amid the inevitable uncertainty when you do not have a permanent manager at either club or country.

    He said: "Yes, it's a strange feeling. But it comes with the territory, it's part of football, part of life.

    "You just try to move forward as a group, whether it's with England or Chelsea."

    By moving on, he actually means aiming for the stars with the Blues and the Three Lions.

    Chelsea are chasing the Champions League, FA Cup and a top-four finish, ensuring a dramatic climax to the season. Then come the Euros.

    And Dan the Man said: "At Chelsea we want to finish the season off as well as we can, we have some big games coming up and if we can finish the season with some silverware it would be fantastic.

    "I am confident. I think it's going to be very exciting."

    But then life is never boring when you are Daniel Sturridge.

pages.subdeck: BA OF GOLD ... Newcastle freebie Demba Ba has been the bargain of the season
pages.headline: Top 10 Premier League freebies
pages.teaser: CHECK out who joins Demba Ba in SunSport's top 10 Premier League free transfers
pages.articlebody:
FREEBIE Demba Ba was recently voted the player most Premier League managers wish they had signed last summer.

Newcastle were the lucky recipients of the hotshot's services, exploiting a clause in his contract at relegated West Ham to snap him up for nothing.

The Senegalese striker has since gone on to score 16 goals for them in the top flight and has spearheaded the Toon's climb to sixth spot in the league.

In light of Ba's sensational season on Tyneside, SunSport have put together a top 10 list of the best free transfer signings in Premier League history.

No chance of costly flops Winston Bogarde, Joe Cole or Marouane Chamakh being included, then...

1. Sol Campbell

THE former England defender was the ultimate freebie.

Raised from a youth player to club captain at Tottenham, Campbell incensed the White Hart Lane faithful by moving to Arsenal in 2001 for absolutely nothing.

He proved to be an excellent signing for Arsene Wenger and helped the Gunners to two Premier League titles and three FA Cup trophies.

2. Demba Ba

GOALSCORERS in the Premier League are a priceless commodity that usually cost top whack.

And for that reason, Newcastle have been laughing all the way to the bank since picking up Ba for free after West Ham's relegation.

The ex-Hoffenheim forward is on 16 league goals and counting this campaign which really puts the likes of £50million Fernando Torres and £35m Andy Carroll to shame.

3. Brad Friedel

IT took Friedel a while to find his feet in the Premier League.

But what an impact he made when he finally got to grips with England's top flight.

After a disappointing spell at Liverpool, the American moved to Blackburn on a Bosman and proved himself to be one of the most dependable keepers to grace these shores  as Tottenham observed when snapping him up on a free from Aston Villa last summer.

4. Jay-Jay Okocha

SAM ALLARDYCE was at his wheeler-dealing best when he brought in Okocha.

His big-money move to PSG hadn't worked out and he was allowed to leave when his contract expired, opening the door for Allardyce's charm offensive.

Big Sam convinced the Nigerian that the Reebok Stadium was the place to be and Okocha went on to become a darling of the Trotters' faithful.

5. Kevin Davies

IF Bolton's signing of Okocha was left-field, then picking up Davies when his career had hit rock bottom seemed plain crazy.

It proved to be a stroke of genius though as Allardyce transformed the former Blackburn flop into a bruising centre-forward that no one fancied playing against.

Davies may be in the twilight of his career now but he has been a loyal servant to Wanderers over the last nine years and was rewarded with an England cap in October 2010.

6. Mark Schwarzer

AGED 35 and out of contract at Middlesbrough, few could be forgiven for thinking Schwarzer's best days were behind him.

But the Aussie stopper proved the doubters wrong when he signed for Fulham and became one of the most consistent keepers in the league.

He played a pivotal role in the Cottagers run to the Europa League final in 2010 and was even the subject of a failed £2m bid from Arsenal the following summer.

7. Gary McAllister

THE average central-midfielder is over the hill by 35  but McAllister was no ordinary player.

The bald Scot was 20 years into a stellar career when Gerard Houllier offered him the opportunity of a shock switch to Liverpool.

McAllister grabbed it with both hands and became an integral member of the Reds' quintuple-winning season.

8. Ivan Campo

DAVID LUIZ'S bushy-haired bretheren loved his loan spell at Bolton so much, he gave up life in sunny Spain to sign for the Trotters in 2003.

Campo fitted in perfectly with the physicality of English football and became yet another of Allardyce's bargain buys.

The Spaniard may have won two Champions League titles during his time at Real Madrid, but he'll always have a stronger rapport with the Bolton fans after five years at the Reebok.

9. Sylvain Distin

YOU have to wonder if Distin regrets leaving Manchester City, just as the times were getting good.

Probably not, considering City were still chopping and changing their manager while he was winning the FA Cup with Portsmouth.

The French star formed a rock-solid partnership with fellow freebie Sol Campbell at Pompey and was so good that the South-Coast club even made a tasty £5m profit on him when he moved to Everton.

10. Mathieu Flamini

FLAMINI'S career underlines the power players received after the creation of the Bosman ruling.

There was no room for sentiment as the Frenchman left Marseille for nothing to sign for Arsenal in 2004 and then repeated the process four years later to head to AC Milan.

Despite leaving the Gunners profitless, Flamini was still a bargain signing for the North Londoners who used his versatility to great effect in their run to the 2006 Champions League final.

pages.subdeck: SHOW OF SUPPORT ... fans spell out Fabrice Muamba's name in card tribute ahead of kick-off yesterday
pages.headline: Road to recovery
pages.teaser: YESTERDAY was another good day on the road to recovery for Fabrice Muamba
pages.articlebody:
THE applause was supposed to last for a minute.

In the end, it went on for a good five.

Young and old, big and small, fans of both Bolton Wanderers and Blackburn Rovers gave it their very best.

United by Fabrice Muamba, their old Lancashire rivalry suspended for a brief time.

Muamba may not have been there but he was foremost in everyone's thoughts.

Still seriously ill in hospital in East London, he will, nonetheless, have drawn immense strength from news of early Bolton goals at the Reebok.

Some will suggest that a relegation six-pointer pales into insignificance alongside what Muamba has been through since collapsing with a heart attack at White Hart Lane a week ago.

But, to the player, it will have been vitally important. And when the news of Bolton's victory finally filtered through to Bethnal Green, I'm sure it would have meant the world to him.

To know there was a little light at the end of the tunnel in his club's own fight for survival.

No doubt, he was kicking every ball. And, as best he could, joining in the applause.

And so everyone connected with Bolton finally got on with life yesterday. It was a day when even the sun came out for 23-year-old Muamba.

The Reebok is not known for the clemency of its weather.

Situated as it is underneath the aptly-named Winter Hill, it's one of the bleakest spots in the country, chill winds invading the very marrow of your bones.

Yesterday, though, it was bathed in sunshine. Suddenly, we were in Bolton-sur-mer. Smiling faces all round, girls in shorts and fans from both clubs gathered to see their teams do exactly as Muamba had wished  to get on with the game.

Outside the stadium, they read the messages of support.

On the ground outside the main reception area, there were shirts from probably every club in the land. And all with the same message.

Get well soon, Fabrice. Keep fighting. We're thinking of you.

Strangely, there was a sign on the wall saying In Remembrance.

Thankfully, this is not the case for young Fabrice, following his near-miraculous and ongoing recovery after his heart effectively stopped for 78 minutes last weekend.

There were further tributes to a player referred to as Lionheart. And an England shirt with the words Bulldog Spirit.

All very British and gung-ho.

Except Muamba is far from your average football player. He is a one-off, a man of his own making.

It takes a special person to arrive at a tender age from a country at war like the Congo and settle as well as he did.

To learn a foreign language in quick time and go on to pass three A levels.

And the whole time making an impression on the football pitch. Everyone has talked of what a delight Muamba is, considerate, patient and without a trace of conceit or envy.

How he has a kind word for everyone.

And also the time to take an Open University course in accountancy and attend church every Sunday.

As I said, far removed from the public perception of a Premier League footballer.

This, more than anything, is why we had a packed Reebok yesterday. Some 26,901, the biggest crowd of the season.

They had come to cheer their team and also say thank you. Thank you for Muamba being spared. And thank you for that rarity  a gentleman in sport. With the emphasis on 'gentle'.

As the players walked out, we were supposed to start our minute's applause. But it had already started.

And prompted, fair play to them, by the chants of "Fabrice Muamba" from the visiting fans.

As the applause continued, fans in the sun-drenched East Stand held up cards spelling "Muamba 6".

High to their right, the big screen recalled highlights of his career. And still the applause rang out. Then it was down to the other business of the day. And even there the sun radiated down on Bolton.

David Wheater powered home one header after 28 minutes, then another seven minutes later. And all was well with the world.

The name of the absent hero once again reverberated round the stadium.

Of course, these things never quite work to script. So we had Blackburn's Steven Nzonzi pulling one back with over half an hour left and high anxiety gripping the home fans.

Then, after a seeming eternity, a blast on referee Andre Marriner's whistle announced it was over and Bolton were out of the bottom three.

Yes, salvation may still be some way off.

But for Bolton and Fabrice Muamba, yesterday was another good day on the road to recovery.

pages.headline: Now you'll know what squeaky bum time is
pages.teaser: ALEX FERGUSON has warned Roberto Mancini he will find out exactly what 'squeaky bum time' is in the next few weeks
pages.articlebody:
ALEX FERGUSON has warned Roberto Mancini he will find out exactly what 'squeaky bum time' is in the next seven weeks.

Manchester City's Italian boss celebrated his team's crucial win over Chelsea on Wednesday by using one of Fergie's favourite phrases.

The two rivals will go toe-to-toe at the top of the table between now and May 13.

But Manchester United chief Ferguson says his team have proved time and time again they have the bottle to go the distance.

Asked whether Mancini really knew what 'Squeaky Bum Time' means, Fergie said: "He will in the next few weeks!"

City look to have the stronger squad following their spending spree but the Old Trafford boss says that does not always matter.

He said: "What's more important in the run-in is how the temperament is, how they hold their nerve.

"You look at it over the years. Last season we were 1-0 down at Blackburn and we needed a point to win the league.

"The energy of the team was unbelievable, it was incessant pressure until we got the penalty.

"We didn't bottle it and we never showed any signs of anxiety or nerves, we just kept on playing.

"Experience is important. It doesn't matter who you are, if you've been there before, it helps."

Ferguson is starting the mind games but he concedes the 'noisy neighbours' in Sky Blue have made huge progress.

He said: "City have done exceptionally well and they've been top of the league for a long time.

"In many ways they're in the driving seat because they've got us to come to the Etihad.

"What we've got to get used to  and it's the same for every United and City fan  is there's going to be big games involving the two teams for the next decade.

"It will be semi-finals and finals, whatever, because the two teams will be at the forefront."

pages.headline: We'll have to win all our games
pages.teaser: BLUES boss admits that Champions League bid is a long shot after draw v Spurs
pages.articlebody:
ROBERTO DI MATTEO admits Chelsea need to win all eight remaining Premier League games to have a hope of making next season's Champions League.

The Blues still trail Tottenham by five points after a Stamford Bridge stalemate with Harry Redknapp's side.

And Di Matteo said: "It's going to be difficult now but there are still eight games to play. To make the gap up we have to win all of them.

"Fourth spot is very important for this club."

Chelsea, who could also qualify by winning the Champions League, have away days at Arsenal and Liverpool as well as a home clash with Newcastle.

Spurs' run-in is not as daunting which is why Redknapp wants third.

He said: "It's not a done deal that Arsenal will finish third. We have to win six of the last eight.

"We would have a chance if we did that."

CHELSEA have stolen a march on home and European rivals by opening talks to sign Napoli's prolific marksman Edinson Cavani.

Representatives of the 25-year-old Uruguayan were in London on Friday to discuss a proposed £30million transfer to Stamford Bridge, even though Chelsea are currently managerless after the sacking of Andre Villas-Boas.

Cavani's stock continues to rise as he took his tally to 26 goals this term with a double strike to book Napoli's place in the final of the Coppa Italia in midweek.

Napoli maintain it will take a king's ransom to secure him  but Italian sources still believe they will cash in this summer.

Chelsea have been tracking the star and are in a position of strength compared to Premier League rivals.

Liverpool would like to pair him with his compatriot Luis Suarez but would need to finance the move by selling Andy Carroll.

Manchester City are also keen but to address new financial fair play rules they would need to sell before recruiting.

Chelsea's biggest competition will come from Real Madrid, Inter Milan and Bayern Munich.

pages.subdeck: PETER'S PERFECT ... Crouch's stunning volley gives Stoke City the lead
pages.headline: Stoke City 1 Man City 1
pages.teaser: PETER CROUCH smashed a wonder goal to shell-shock Man City but Yaya Toure hit back with a long range strike of his own as Roberto Mancini's side showed they are well up for the fight
pages.articlebody:
PETER CROUCH smashed a wonder goal to shell-shock Man City.

But Yaya Toure hit back with a long range strike of his own as Roberto Mancini's side edged back in front of their arch rivals in the red half of Manchester.

What little action happened in the first hour was all but forgotten when Crouch delivered a stupendous two-touch control and volley from 30 yards that flew over Joe Hart and became the main - if not ONLY - contender for goal of the season.

The game has started in timid fashion. The injured Sergio Aguero was replaced by Edin Dzeko and Carlos Tevez was again on the bench but the visitors did control the early possession.

But it was not until the ninth minute that Gael Clichy found space to deliver a ball into the Stoke box but Asmir Begovic claimed easily.

Stoke had their first opening after a free-kick was crossed to the back post for Crouch but Cameron Jerome was unable to turn his downward header goalwards.

At the other end, David Silva and Pablo Zabaleta both had efforts deflected wide and Yaya Toure shot over from distance.

Dean Whitehead was given a talking to by referee Howard Webb after catching Silva with his arm challenging for a high ball, with play held up while the Spaniard received treatment.

Stoke almost took the lead in the 41st minute when a Matthew Etherington corner was met by a deft glancing header from Ryan Shawcross but Pablo Zabaleta cleared off the line.

Mario Balotelli broke through as the first half went into injury time but shot tamely at Begovic.

Dzeko had a chance to break the deadlock in the opening minute of the second half as he controlled a lofted pass from Barry, but he could not get it down quick enough to round Begovic.

Cameron Jerome was replaced by Jermaine Pennant in the 51st minute and Hart was forced to block an effort from Walters at point-blank range.

Stoke claimed the lead with a sensational strike from Crouch just before the hour.

A long clearance from Begovic was headed on by the lanky front man, before he took the return from Pennant, flicked it up and twisted to volley over Hart and into the top corner.

Mancini reacted by sending on Adam Johnson for Silva and then Tevez for Barry in the hope of gaining more width.

But it was Yaya Toure from a central position - a non-threatening 35 yards out - who sledgehammered in the equaliser.

The Ivorian's firecracker caught the head of Shawcross and it was enough to wrong-foot Begovic and slam into the net.

Pulis introduced Wilson Palacios in place of Etherington to shore up his side and Shawcross came close with a header that looped agonisingly over.

Yaya Toure came close at the death but another powerful effort from the all-action midfielder flew just over the top.
